cc @dramaticlly @RussellSpitzer @nastra @advancedxy code has rebased, please take a look when you are free.

> Merged, thanks @jerqi . Can you please update the pr description to make it clearer what problem we are fixing? And do we need to make the fix for other Spark versions?

1. ok, I will update the pr description.
2. ok, I will raise another pr to fix Spark 3.5.

@szehon-ho I have raised a new pr for Spark 3.5. https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/8584/files
I think Arrow is not a storage format. It is a memory format. However, a storage like Parquet/orc/avro defines how data are stored.
@jackye1995 do you know if the `iceberg-build.properties` file is being removed for EMR?
Thanks @nastra
Ping
I think it would be great to get this in 1.4.0 as well. @ebyhr can you add a test so we can get this in? Thanks!
I have rebased the master branch and modify the code of Spark 3.5. Gently ping @RussellSpitzer @aokolnychyi

@rdblue @Fokko here's a proposal for ASF DOAP rdf file.

Few comments:
- the ASL license link is correct (generated by the ASF tool)
- I validated the RDF file on the RDF validator
- when this PR will be merged, I will update the ASF records

Thanks !
Thanks for your reviews! CI is green now.

> @Jack Ye do you know if the `iceberg-build.properties` file is being removed for EMR?

Hey @nastra , it may be removed as I always get this in my logs using emr serverless:
```
23/09/19 08:03:43 WARN IcebergBuild: Failed to load version properties from /iceberg-build.properties
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: resource /iceberg-build.properties relative to org.apache.iceberg.IcebergBuild not found.
```

> I think we should also apply this against Spark 3.5 now

@nastra should we do it with a follow-up PR to port the changes to other spark versions? Because it exists in all other spark versions.
Thanks for fixing this @ebyhr, and @nastra & @ajantha-bhat for the review
LGTM, thanks (FYI, I can't add a formal review as my user is not in the iceberg group).

> We might have to raise issue to RevAPI to track this

It was not an issue with RevAPI itself, but rather with Gradle. Something in the execution changed that would cause RevAPI failures to not be detected properly.
Is this still an issue with Gradle 8.3?
Follow-up PR is fine IMO (whatever you prefer)
@stevenzwu @pvary I addressed the feedback, a couple of items I left as-is and left a comment in case you wanted to review.

```
TestStructuredStreamingRead3 > [catalogName = testhive, implementation = org.apache.iceberg.spark.SparkCatalog, config = {type=hive, default-namespace=default}] > testReadingStreamFromFutureTimetsamp[catalogName = testhive, implementation = org.apache.iceberg.spark.SparkCatalog, config = {type=hive, default-namespace=default}] FAILED
```

this is a flaky test?
Hi @aokolnychyi, @rdblue, can you take a look at the spec change? If it looks good, we'll move ahead with the merge.
Let me check in a bit.
Let me know once there is PR, @jbonofre.

@clettieri, sorry it took so long to get back to this PR.

Could you, please, add tests that the new name is also supported in CREATE TABLE statements too? I believe this change only covers ALTER TABLE. In addition, this PR should be rebased and include Spark 3.5.
Thanks, @RussellSpitzer @rdblue @Fokko!
I'm going to close this because @aokolnychyi is right: we handle IN this way because we have special checks within the NOT conversion that ensure we don't negate an IN expression. Thanks, Anton!
@Fokko ok, all tests passed now, thank you for the review! would you mind taking another look?
Rebased latest upstream and added corresponding change in spark 3.5 as well
I think one option we looked into in the past is using rewrite-all option, can read more in https://iceberg.apache.org/javadoc/1.3.1/org/apache/iceberg/actions/BinPackStrategy.html#REWRITE_ALL

> @stevenzwu: Extracting the partition key from the row is on the hot path of writes. Based on the code I do not see any obvious issues, but it might worth to check the performance implications of this change?

@pvary there is no change in the logic. simple refactor with a common base class extracted. so I don't expect performance  implications

@stevenzwu  I reverted things back to use a `Supplier<Table>` instead of a `TableLoader`. The only open comment is whether to remove `isOpen()` from the `TableLoader` interface, currently it is still being used in the new table supplier.

Have you solved this problem?
I have the same issue

> @stevenzwu I reverted things back to use a `Supplier<Table>` instead of a `TableLoader`. The only open comment is whether to remove `isOpen()` from the `TableLoader` interface, currently it is still being used in the new table supplier.

thanks. I think we are very close now. left a few minor comments

> thanks. I think we are very close now. left a few minor comments

Thanks for your patience. I made the changes except refreshing in the supplier `get()`. I tend to agree w/ Peter that it should be refreshed only during the checkpoint, but I'm happy to change it back.
thanks for the reviews everyone
@ConeyLiu since you had a similar PR, could you review this one as well please?

> > @stevenzwu: Extracting the partition key from the row is on the hot path of writes. Based on the code I do not see any obvious issues, but it might worth to check the performance implications of this change?
> 
> @pvary there is no change in the logic. simple refactor with a common base class extracted. so I don't expect performance implications

Previous code had 1 less redirection/inheritance. Optimized loops can be a thing in this type of code paths, where the compiler could deduce that the different iterations of the loops are independent, and could be executed in batch. Adding more redirection/inheritance could break the optimization algorithm and instead of a parallel loop we can end up executing the loop sequentially. This could cause performance degradation. This is the only effect which might effect other users of the classes touched by this change, otherwise I think the change keeps the old behaviour correctly and introduces a new one, which we need.
@aokolnychyi Hey Anton. I'm rebasing and doing new tests, I should be able to open the PR later today or tomorrow.
Thanks @nastra for merging this. And thanks @dramaticlly @advancedxy for the review. I will submit a backport.

A first step would be to add metrics for the list itself to Parquet. However, this will require upstream changes to Parquet (which I'm happy to do):

![image](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/assets/1134248/59197329-ef74-41aa-aed3-a7b3c5f5ca0a)

It looks like it combines the list column and its elements in a single column.

@maxdebayser Thanks for working on this, and for your patience because it took quite a while, and we also went a bit back and forth. Let's merge this in. As a next step, we can revisit https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/8012 and add a lot of integration tests to make sure that we don't have any correctness issues. 

I think there are still some open-ends on the statistics, but they are not limited to Python. Please refer to https://github.com/apache/iceberg/issues/8598
Thanks @rdblue for the review, that was very helpful.
Thanks @wypoon, just some minor comments.
Thanks, @Fokko and @rdblue

Hello 
Has anyone been able to find a solution to this

@amogh-jahagirdar pointed out that we already check and do not delete files that were committed. In that case, we want the set of delete files to be any file that was ever deleted and we don't need to clear the set. Thanks for digging in and finding the right answer, Amogh!

There are no upper and lower on the list both in Parquet and ORC:

![image](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/assets/1134248/538c5452-5cd8-4bad-bb22-c45350b3e20b)
On the community sync was decided to drop the null-counts for the map/list, and make sure that they are populated correctly for the nested structs.

@stevenzwu We'd also need this to be set when using Flink SQL. I was considering removing `FlinkSink.tableRefreshInterval()` and using a configuration. Can you advise on what that best approach would be for this?
Szehon is on parental leave. I took his work and added Spark 3.5 changes in #8593. Closing this.
Perfect, please tag it here for visibility.
Actually I can remove the override for RestCatalog now that this is default. Let me clean that up as well.

> @clettieri, sorry it took so long to get back to this PR.
> 
> Could you, please, add tests that the new name is also supported in CREATE TABLE statements too? I believe this change only covers ALTER TABLE. In addition, this PR should be rebased and include Spark 3.5.

Hey @aokolnychyi, I can rebase and include Spark 3.5 👍🏼 .

Regarding the CREATE TABLE tests though, I don't see any for the previous transform functions and am unclear what new functionality they would test compared to what we have now.  The current tests seem sufficient IMO to validate the transform functions can be called.  Am I missing something here?  Should I create a new test class to verify creating tables with these transform functions succeed?

Thanks!
Thanks, @amogh-jahagirdar!
@RussellSpitzer @flyrain @rdblue, could you review this?
cc @Fokko @amogh-jahagirdar @nastra @rdblue @RussellSpitzer @flyrain

> From @deniskuzZ comment (thanks Denys for the information), we can see that by default the session timezone used by Hive is the JVM timezone.

The question isn't how the default is determined. What we need to know is how the session time zone is passed. This uses the default JVM timezone not the session timezone, which seems incorrect to me.

I made the change to move the refresh interval config to a write property, and removed the config method in `FlinkSink`. This allows the option to be used in Flink SQL also. Apologies for the last minute change.
Thanks @nastra @rdblue @aokolnychyi for quick reviews on this. Merging
@manhtaile Thanks for the PR, it looks great! Can you add the sort order as well?
Looks good to me.
Thanks, @rdblue!
Thanks, @Fokko @RussellSpitzer!
cc @amogh-jahagirdar @flyrain @RussellSpitzer

If these only test the overhead in a local context, are we worried there may be a time where performance in a local context would become worse with a code change but performance in a distributed context would be better?
@RussellSpitzer, these benchmarks can be used to profile local planning too. I was just explaining why distributed planning can't be faster and why the numbers look worse.

> @RussellSpitzer, these benchmarks can be used to profile local planning too. I was just explaining why distributed planning can't be faster and why the numbers look worse.

Yeah I understand that I was thinking more of the context of comparing changes to Distributed Planning.

Given theoretical distributed benchmark distBench we may see something like

|Benchmark | Version A | Version B|
|-----------|-----------|----------|
| localBench | 10 | 5 | 
| distBench  | 5  |  10 |
 
 In this case while our local benchmark for distributed planning looks better, the actual perf would be worse
@RussellSpitzer, got you. Yeah, we can't benchmark the distributed planning locally for sure. However, it is still beneficial for local profiling. It helped me quite a bit to reduce the overhead.
SGTM, Just want to make sure we don't have this as the only gatekeeping on perf improvements to Dist Planning
@RussellSpitzer, 100%. The biggest issue is usually the speed with which we can fetch the result from other nodes. That can only be tested on a real cluster.
@clettieri, what about `TestCreateTable`? Unlike what is covered by new tests, we should also check the new syntax is supported by Spark without extensions.

hello @CFan7, can you give me an example of compress parquet to gzip , my wish is when i query it to output gzip file , i am working with iceberg table and i am using pyspark language,recommend using  property write.parquet.compression-codec

Mycode:
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

spark = SparkSession.builder \
    .appName("CSVICEBERG") \
    .config("spark.jars.packages", "org.apache.iceberg:iceberg-spark-runtime-3.4_2.12:1.3.0") \
    .config("spark.sql.extensions", "org.apache.iceberg.spark.extensions.IcebergSparkSessionExtensions") \
    .config("spark.sql.catalog.spark_catalog", "org.apache.iceberg.spark.SparkSessionCatalog") \
    .config("spark.sql.catalog.spark_catalog.type", "hive") \
    .config("spark.sql.catalog.local", "org.apache.iceberg.spark.SparkCatalog") \
    .config("spark.sql.catalog.local.type", "hadoop") \
    .config("spark.sql.catalog.local.warehouse", "D:\iceberg_warehouse") \
    .config("spark.sql.defaultCatalog", "local") \
    .config("spark.sql.parquet.compression.codec", "gzip") \
    .config("write.parquet.compression-codec", "gzip") \
    .getOrCreate()
spark.conf.set("write.parquet.compression-codec", "gzip")
spark.sql("CREATE TABLE local.test.cnd10 (name STRING,id INT) using iceberg")
spark.sql("INSERT INTO local.test.cnd10 values ('ABC',1) ")
Thanks @nastra @advancedxy

@NhatDuy11 and @Silver-PN, 

It is a table property. Not a spark property. 
In the create table SQL we can specify the table property. 

```
spark.sql("CREATE TABLE local.test.cnd10 (name STRING,id INT) using iceberg TBLPROPERTIES ('write.parquet.compression-codec' = 'gzip')")
  ```
  
  There is an option to specify them as table-default properties at the catalog level aswell as mentioned by the last two entries of table https://iceberg.apache.org/docs/latest/spark-configuration/#catalog-configuration

@ajantha-bhat hello,
I tried your method again but still did not receive the gzip file, only received the parquet file when querying
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

spark = SparkSession.builder \
    .appName("CSVICEBERG") \
    .config("spark.jars.packages", "org.apache.iceberg:iceberg-spark-runtime-3.4_2.12:1.3.0") \
    .config("spark.sql.extensions", "org.apache.iceberg.spark.extensions.IcebergSparkSessionExtensions") \
    .config("spark.sql.catalog.spark_catalog", "org.apache.iceberg.spark.SparkSessionCatalog") \
    .config("spark.sql.catalog.spark_catalog.type", "hive") \
    .config("spark.sql.catalog.local", "org.apache.iceberg.spark.SparkCatalog") \
    .config("spark.sql.catalog.local.type", "hadoop") \
    .config("spark.sql.catalog.local.warehouse", "D:\iceberg_warehouse") \
    .config("spark.sql.defaultCatalog", "local") \
    .config("write.parquet.compression-codec","gzip")\
    .getOrCreate()
    spark.sql("CREATE TABLE local.dcn.two (name STRING ,age INT) USING iceberg TBLPROPERTIES('write.parquet.compression-codec'='gzip')").show()
spark.sql("insert into local.dcn.two values ('duy',1) ").show()
spark.sql("SELECT * FROM  local.dcn.two ").show()

> I tried your method again but still did not receive the gzip file, only received the parquet file when querying

How do you know the parquet file is not compressed with gzip?
Thanks for raising this. I wasn't able to reproduce this with a rest catalog, let me set up a hive catalog.
